courseDescription: This course is designed especially for those entering the health education or health care field, covering the physiology of each of the major body systems as a basis for understanding those aspects of its function that reflect the importance of various nutrients.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of nutrient function within body systems
Application of nutritional principles in health care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a healthcare setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of physiological responses to nutrients

courseDescription: This course will explore the history of health equity and disability and how prejudice and discrimination against people with disabilities impact health. Students will learn how to apply health equity frameworks, theories, and research to address disability-specific models of health disparities and to achieve health equity in populations with disabilities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and empathizing with people with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theories to achieve health equity

courseDescription: This course provides a population-based approach to professional work in disease management, chronic care management and politics, in addition to students studying public health, health policy, quality and patient safety, health care administration, medicine, nursing, pharmacy, social work and other related clinical professions.

The uniqueness of the U.S. healthcare delivery system will be explored in terms of a systems framework and its complexity. The basic characteristics that differentiate the U.S. healthcare delivery system from that of other countries will be presented. An understanding of the U.S. health care system has specific implications for health services managers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of U.S. Healthcare Delivery System

courseTitle: Interprofessional Study Abroad on Global Health
courseDescription: This study abroad service learning course will introduce the student to the political, social, cultural, and ethical issues involved in prevention and health promotion globally. Students will travel to another country and learn the incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified public health problems in specific regions and countries.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing social and cultural factors influencing health

courseDescription: Identifies major issues and problems in meeting health care needs of the aged. Emphasis on role of social assets and supports in determining effects of life changes on the aging process.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and empathizing with aging individuals' life changes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing health care issues for the aged
Analyzing effects of social assets and supports on the aging process
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading support groups for the aged
Coordinating health care needs for the aged

courseTitle: Community Health Resources and Health Promotion
courseDescription: Designed to provide information about community health resources and health promotion theory. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital platforms for health promotion
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of health promotion theory
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading health promotion efforts in the community

courseDescription: This course covers financial management functions in healthcare organizations including operating and capital budgeting processes along with budgeting and financial controls.

This course focuses on health services research and its assessment abilities and application in health care and public health. Topics include the use of EXCEL, SAS, and SPSS to analyze data. An exploration of the issues and challenges of health services research for health related organizations and other organizations. Statistical procedures and practices will also be conducted.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and addressing challenges in health services research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying research findings in health care and public health

courseDescription: A review of the principles and practice of administering public and community health organizations and programs at federal, state, and local levels. Constitutional, statutory and administrative bases for organizing and conducting public/community health programs will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with federal, state, and local health regulations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating effectiveness of public/community health programs
Identifying potential legal issues in health administration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing health programs at different administrative levels

courseDescription: This course will blend theory and application of epidemiology. This course will also provide a comprehensive introduction to epidemiology and explain how to use epidemiological concepts and tools to improve decisions about the management of health services.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making in health services management

courseDescription: This course will explore both health policy and the politics of health. Students will develop an understanding of the systematic and analytical framework for developing health and health care policy issues.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion on policy issues

courseDescription: The internship will allow a student new to the health administration field or public health field to complete a capstone internship to gain entry skills for a beginning career pathway in the profession. The course is intended to provide field experience and assimilation of the theoretical aspects learned in the coursework in a practical/work setting. A minimum of 200 hours is required for the 3-credit internship.

This course provides a basic understanding of marketing in a health care setting. It will cover the following: the history of marketing in a health care setting, health care markets, marketing techniques, and leadership skills in managing and supporting the marketing efforts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of marketing techniques in a health care setting
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating marketing efforts to the team
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of marketing techniques

courseDescription: This course provides the students with a basic knowledge of health law and examines legal issues confronting health services administrators in various health care environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with legal issues in health care environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with health services administrators
Negotiation and conflict resolution within legal contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of legal issues in health care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of legal issues in health services administration

courseDescription: This course focuses on healthcare informatics (information systems) and applications in health care organizations. It provides an overview of health information system concepts, management, and integration of technology in healthcare organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of technology in healthcare organizations

courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity for the study of selected topics in public/community health under the supervision of a faculty member.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution development for community health issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in community outreach programs

courseTitle: Directed Research in Health Services Administration
courseDescription: Supervised research on a specific problem in health services administration. Regular meetings with faculty and a written/oral report are required.
Identifies major issues and problems in meeting health care needs of the aged. Emphasis on role of social assets and supports in determining effects of life changes on the aging process.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis of social factors impacting health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of health issues in aged individuals
Assessment of life changes impact on aging process
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organization of suitable healthcare for aged
Leadership in healthcare context for the aged

courseTitle: Community Health Resources and Health Promotion
courseDescription: Designed to provide information about community health resources and health promotion theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research and identification of community health resources
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for community health improvement

courseDescription: This course covers financial management functions in healthcare organizations including operating and capital budgeting processes along with budgeting and financial controls.

This course focuses on health services research and its assessment abilities and application in health care and public health. Topics include the use of EXCEL, SAS, and SPSS to analyze data. An exploration of the issues and challenges of health services research for health related organizations and other organizations. Statistical procedures and practices will also be conducted.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of statistical procedures and practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex health service research findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing issues and challenges in health services research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and conducting health services research
Leading health services research initiatives within organizations

courseDescription: A review of the principles and practice of administering public and community health organizations and programs at federal, state, and local levels. Constitutional, statutory and administrative bases for organizing and conducting public/community health programs will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public and community health organizations
Knowledge of federal, state, and local health programs
Familiarity with constitutional, statutory and administrative bases for health programs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to liaise with various levels of government and health organizations
Ability to clearly communicate health administration principles and practices
Ability to discuss and explain statutory and administrative bases for health programs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and evaluate health administration principles
Ability to identify potential issues in the administration of public/community health programs
Ability to solve administrative problems in public and community health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to administer and manage health organizations and programs
Understanding of leadership roles in public and community health
Ability to organize public/community health programs

courseDescription: This course will blend theory and application of epidemiology. This course will also provide a comprehensive introduction to epidemiology and explain how to use epidemiological concepts and tools to improve decisions about the management of health services.

This course will explore both health policy and the politics of health. Students will develop an understanding of the systematic and analytical framework for developing health and health care policy issues.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical framework development for health care issues

courseDescription: This course provides a basic understanding of marketing in a health care setting. This course will cover the following: the history of marketing in a health care setting, health care markets, marketing techniques, and leadership skills in managing and supporting the marketing efforts.
This course provides the students with a basic knowledge of health law and examines legal issues confronting health services administrators in various health care environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of legal issues in health care environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation and conflict resolution in legal contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing legal issues in health care
Problem-solving in health care legal situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Decision-making in legal health care contexts
Leadership in handling legal issues in health care

courseDescription: This course focuses on healthcare informatics (information systems) and application in health care organizations. It provides an overview of health information system concepts, management, and integration of technology in healthcare organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of technology in healthcare organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating technical information to non-technical personnel
Liaising between healthcare professionals and IT professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying opportunities for technology integration in healthcare
Analyzing health information systems for improvement

courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity for the study of selected topics in public/community health under the supervision of a faculty member.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cross-cultural communication in public health settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of public/community health issues

courseDescription: This seminar will provide students with an understanding of health care organizations and effective management. Particular attention will be given to the issues of access, cost and quality.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing quality issues in health care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading health care quality improvement initiatives

courseTitle: Interprofessional Study Abroad on Global Health
courseDescription: This study abroad service learning course will introduce the student to the political, social, cultural, and ethical issues involved in prevention and health promotion globally. Students will travel another country and learn the incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified public health problems in specific regions and countries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identify and understand regional and country-specific health problems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a foreign environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political, social, and ethical issues in global health
Problem identification and prevention strategies in global health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing a study abroad program

courseTitle: Leadership in Complex Systems and Organizations
courseDescription: This course will focus on the leadership that comprises two types: informal and formal leadership. Competencies will include communication, knowledge of health care environment, leadership, professionalism, and business skills.
This course will cover the use of data in health care as well as other informatics applications. Students will explore healthcare technology used to improve the delivery and evaluation of care.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of data in health care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of healthcare data insights

courseDescription: The focus of the course is on the development of system processes to ensure quality health care. The evidence-based model will be applied to organizational systems.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution implementation based on evidence-based models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in healthcare system process change

courseDescription: An overview of measurement theory with emphasis on the development, testing, and refinement of norm- and criterion-referenced data collection instruments for health-related research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Testing and refinement of data collection instruments

courseDescription: This course focuses on the competitive design and utilization of organizational and human resources. Emphasis will be placed on the strategic process to ensure that resources are applied in ways to ensure high-quality care and excellent patient outcomes. The course will cover the business models for effective financial and personnel management of healthcare organizations. Analysis of the costs and quality of care will be performed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a healthcare setting

courseDescription: This course examines epidemiology as a method for viewing inborn community health problems and as a body of knowledge derived from this method. Skills in using epidemiology as a method and as knowledge to solve community health problems will be included.

This course provides an in-depth examination of human genetics, embryologic development and normal physiologic functioning of developing body systems. Mechanisms involved in cell division, gametogenesis, and inheritance patterns will be addressed. Basic genetics and epigenetics will be included. The structural and functional development of fetal systems, during critical periods, will be emphasized. Abnormalities and alterations in fetal development will be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of normal physiologic functioning of developing body systems
Understanding the structural and functional development of fetal systems
Understanding of abnormalities and alterations in fetal development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex genetic and physiological information
Ability to communicate findings and observations regarding fetal development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying knowledge of genetics and physiology to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to organize and interpret complex genetic and physiological data

courseDescription: Lecture 3 hours; 3 credits.  This course describes the application of economic tools to analyze the operation of markets for health care and insurance.  Topics covered include the consumption and costs of health care in the United States, the viewpoints of players in the health care market, and an overview of both supply and demand analysis and cost effectiveness analysis.  Complexities of economics unique to health care will be detailed.  Further, students will employ these principles in several case studies of current and classic issues in health economics. (Cross-listed with CHP 764)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding viewpoints of players in health care market
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding complexities of economics unique to health care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Analyzing current and classic issues in health economics

courseDescription: Global health related field placement (112 hours).

The foundations of advanced neonatal care course provides the theoretical and practical knowledge for the neonatal nurse practitioner or physician assistant to manage the health care needs of the neonate in the newborn nursery or level II neonatal intensive care unit.
Technical and Digital Skills: Level II neonatal intensive care unit operations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with neonatal care team
Empathy and understanding in neonatal care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical decision making in neonatal care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in managing neonatal care
Task delegation in neonatal care team

courseDescription: This course enables the student to develop a systematic and analytical framework for understanding health care policy issues. The policy process is covered in detail. Timely policy issues also are discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of policy issues

courseDescription: This course offers scientific inquiry into the use of pharmacologic agents in the advanced nursing care of infants, including fetal, neonatal life, and early childhood. Pharmacokiinetcs, pharmacodynamics, drug use in pregnancy and lactation, pharmacologic agents used in disease prevention and treatment, drug monitoring and drug safety in the home are explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with drug use in pregnancy and lactation
Proficiency in pharmacologic agents used in disease prevention and treatment
Ability to monitor drug safety in the home environment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with pregnant and lactating mothers regarding drug use
Ability to explain complex pharmacological concepts to non-medical individuals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic data
Assessing drug safety and efficacy in different neonatal stages
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating and managing drug administration in neonatal care
Leading patient education initiatives regarding drug safety in the home

courseTitle: Advanced Neonatal Care: High Risk Management I
courseDescription: This course develops the students' ability to manage high-risk neonates. This is the second of three sequential management courses that provide the theoretical and practical knowledge for the neonatal nurse practitioner to manage the health care needs of the neonate at the highest level of nursing practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Theoretical and practical application of neonatal nursing practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a clinical setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of neonatal care practices

courseTitle: Advanced Neonatal Care: High Risk Management II
courseDescription: An organ systems approach is used to explore the diagnosis and management of neonates requiring surgery and advanced technologies. Additional topics will include developmental follow-up of the medically fragile infant and withdrawal of life support in the NICU.
Technical and Digital Skills: Developmental follow-up of medically fragile infants
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting neonatal health data
Decision-making in the withdrawal of life support
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing follow-up care for medically fragile infants

courseDescription: This course will introduce the student to the political, social, cultural and ethical issues involved in disease prevention and health promotion globally. Specific emphasis will be on incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified health problems in specific regions and countries. This course will also identify international health prerogatives aimed at improving health status through education and intervention.
Technical and Digital Skills: Disease prevention and health promotion strategies
Analyzing health data for specific regions and countries
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical communication regarding sensitive health issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying health problems in specific regions
Analyzing incidence, prevalence, morbidity, mortality data
Designing and implementing health intervention strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing disease prevention initiatives

courseDescription: The goal of this course is to guide students with a public health perspective to develop skills to identify and analyze environmental health problems globally. It is designed to provide knowledge on recognizing and evaluating major environmental health issues and risk factors in developed and developing countries by using group discussions and real-life case studies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for environmental health issues

courseDescription: This course familiarizes students with the basic concepts, issues, theories, approaches and models in evaluation in a global public health context. Students in this course will begin to develop technical skills to conceptualize and design evaluations of global public health programs or projects. These practices include determining which evaluation approach to use in a given context, developing an evaluation plan and appropriate evaluation questions, determining the data needed to answer the evaluation questions and establishing reporting processes to provide information to program developers.

This course will teach students the applications of multidisciplinary competencies towards solving human health challenges. The course will identify all areas of global health issues that require human, veterinary and environmental applications for solutions. One Health One Medicine is an important course for all students in Health or Environmental Sciences that are called upon to integrate multidisciplinary competencies as part of their education and career experiences.

This course examines the interrelationships between individual and societal decisions and the global environment, and analyzes the consequences these interrelationships have for public health and sustainability. The course will review food, environmental quality, climate variability, sea-level rise and public health, homes-workplaces-communities, and environmental health and sustainability in the region, the nation and around the world.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing consequences of human decisions on environment
Identifying sustainable solutions in food and environmental quality
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives for public health and sustainability

courseTitle: Issues and Opportunities in Global Health Research
courseDescription: This course focuses on global health research with an emphasis on cultural, political and economic influences on health in various regions and provides students opportunities to engage in inter-professional teamwork to brainstorm problem-based issues and establish research proposals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cultural, political, and economic influences on health

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in health services or health sciences.
Supervised research on a specialized topic. Can be repeated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of specialized research tools and software

courseDescription: Focuses on the complexities involved in providing health services to populations.  Presents issues related to public health, community health, urban and rural health, healthy people/communities and health care delivery in traditional and non-traditional settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of healthcare delivery in various settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing health service needs for different populations
Developing solutions for health service delivery
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing health service delivery in various settings

courseDescription: This seminar will provide students with an understanding of health care organizations and effective management. Particular attention will be given to the issues of access, cost and quality.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation and articulation of healthcare issues

courseDescription: Examination of various methodologies for designing and conducting public health program evaluation and research. Experimental, quasi-experimental and non-experimental procedures will be covered.  Departmental approval required.

courseTitle: Interprofessional Study Abroad on Global Health
courseDescription: This study abroad service learning course will introduce the student to the political, social, cultural, and ethical issues involved in prevention and health promotion globally. Students will travel another country and learn the incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified public health problems in specific regions and countries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of global health metrics (incidence, prevalence, morbidity, mortality)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical negotiation and decision making in health promotion
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of health promotion strategies
Analysis of political, social, and cultural impacts on health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading in diverse and international settings
Navigating ethical issues in global health

courseTitle: Leadership in Complex Systems and Organizations
courseDescription: This course will focus on the leadership that comprises two types: informal and formal leadership. Competencies will include communication, knowledge of health care environment, leadership, professionalism, and business skills.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and navigating the health care environment

courseDescription: This course will cover the use of data in health care as well as other informatics applications. Students will explore healthcare technology used to improve the delivery and evaluation of care.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading technology adoption in healthcare settings

courseDescription: The focus of the course is on the development of system processes to ensure quality health care. The evidence-based model will be applied to organizational systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying evidence-based model to organizational systems
Development of system processes for quality health care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with healthcare teams to implement system processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of system processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading system process development for healthcare quality

courseTitle: Multidisciplinary Approaches to Health Services Research
courseDescription: Uses theory and research findings from areas such as Biology, Psychology, Sociology, Economics, Urban Studies, and Health Services to achieve an understanding of health services issues and problems.  Emphasizes methods of analysis and of developing alternatives related to multidisciplinary perspectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interpreting data from various fields such as Biology, Psychology, Sociology, Economics, Urban Studies, and Health Services
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing alternatives for health services issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on health services issues

courseDescription: Emphasis is on exploring the advantages/disadvantages and uses of non-experimental, quasi-experimental, and experimental designs in health-related research with application to management, education, and clinical practice. (cross-listed with PT 810).
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of research concepts in health-related fields
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing advantages and disadvantages of different research designs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research initiatives in management, education, and clinical practice

courseTitle: Quantitative Research Methods in Health Care
courseDescription: An applied approach to the selection and application of bivariate and multivariate statistical techniques in health services research.  Emphasis is placed on handling large data sets and the use of a computer for manipulation of quantitative data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of computer for data manipulation
Application of statistical techniques in health services research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of analysis results to health services research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of large health data sets

courseDescription: An exploration of qualitative research methods including participant observation, ethnography and the generation of grounded theory.  Individual interviews and focus group methods will be covered and historical, content analysis, phenomenological and montage approaches will also be discussed.  Health related examples of published research in a variety of fields will be utilized to exemplify the methods.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating and moderating focus group discussions

courseDescription: An overview of measurement theory with emphasis on the development, testing, and refinement of norm- and criterion-referenced data collection instruments for health-related research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of norm- and criterion-referenced data collection
Critical evaluation of data collection instruments

courseDescription: Introduces the philosophy of science by studying the nature and purposes of theory for the health sciences. Standards for evaluation of theories will be described.  Selected theories and supporting research from the health services literature will be discussed and critically evaluated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and interpreting health services literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and critical evaluation of theories in group settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of supporting research

courseDescription: This course teaches students the art and science of decision making.  It covers expected utility theory, decision tree analysis, cost-benefit analysis, and the psychological aspects of the decision-making process in the context of health policy research.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing decision-making strategies in health policy

courseDescription: This course focuses on the competitive design and utilization of organizational and human resources. Emphasis will be placed on the strategic process to ensure that resources are applied in ways to ensure high-quality care and excellent patient outcomes. The course will cover the business models for effective financial and personnel management of healthcare organizations. Analysis of the costs and quality of care will be performed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Cost and quality of care analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creation and implementation of high-quality care strategies

courseDescription: This course provides the student with an opportunity to analyze the American health care system.  The health care system is composed of complex organizational dynamics and structures which predicate the interaction between the major components of the system: personnel who provide service; institutions in which care is provided; financing mechanisms which pay for care; and the government which attempts to regulate it.  This course is designed for in-depth analysis and synthesis of all aspects of health care delivery with an emphasis on improving the delivery and access to care.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of health care financing mechanisms
Knowledge of government regulations in health care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interaction with major components of the health care system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: In-depth analysis of health care delivery aspects
Synthesis of health care delivery aspects
Improving delivery and access to care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding complex organizational dynamics and structures in health care
Leadership in health care service provision

courseDescription: This course examines epidemiology as a method for viewing inborn community health problems and as a body of knowledge derived from this method.  Skills in using epidemiology as a method and as knowledge to solve community health problems will be included.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using epidemiology as a method for viewing community health problems
Applying epidemiological knowledge to solve health problems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating epidemiological findings to a non-expert audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and analyzing community health problems using epidemiological methods
Applying epidemiological knowledge to devise solutions for community health problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives to address community health problems

courseDescription: This course adopts an applied approach to teaching health professions students the necessary competencies and skills in advanced quantitative methods. Topics include handling missing data, survey design and exploratory factor analysis, mediation and moderation analysis, and an introduction to confirmatory factor analysis and structural equation modeling (SEM).

This course describes the application of economic tools to analyze the operation of markets for health care and insurance.  Topics covered include the consumption and costs of health care in the United States, the viewpoints of players in the health care market, and an overview of both supply and demand analysis and cost effectiveness analysis.  Complexities of economics unique to health care will be detailed.  Further, students will employ these principles in several case studies of current and classic issues in health economics. (Cross-listed with CHP 764)
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of economic tools in health care
Supply and demand analysis in health care
Cost effectiveness analysis in health care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of health care consumption and costs
Understanding complexities of economics unique to health care
Problem-solving in health economics through case studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding viewpoints of players in health care market
Organizing and presenting complex economic data

courseDescription: Supervised health services field experiences or health sciences laboratory experiences.  A completed research project which is publishable or presentable at a professional conference is required to complete the course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a professional environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in a health sciences context
Analytical skills in a research setting

courseDescription: This course enables the student to develop a systematic and analytical framework for understanding health care policy issues.  The policy process is covered in detail.  Timely policy issues are also discussed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing systematic and analytical framework for health policy issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and following the policy process
Addressing and managing timely policy issues

courseTitle: Planning Proposals and Developing Grants in Health Research
courseDescription: Designed as a 'hand-on' approach in effective grantsmanship, this course will guide the student from the identification of potential funding sources through proposal development.  Highlights include program planning, nonprofit status, governmental/foundation corporate trends, local resources and grants administration.

This course emphasizes the principles and processes of program planning, including a consideration of objectives, priorities, policy choices, assessment of resources, implementation, and evaluation.  The student will gain practical experience in program development by developing a planning document.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of planning objectives and priorities
Ability to present and explain policy choices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of program objectives and priorities
Analysis and evaluation of program outcomes

courseDescription: This course will introduce the student to the political, social, cultural and ethical issues involved in disease prevention and health promotion globally. Specific emphasis will be on incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified health problems in specific regions and countries. This course will also identify international health prerogatives aimed at improving health status through education and intervention.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of health problems in specific regions and countries

courseDescription: This course will assist students in developing a dissertation proposal.  Steps in the research process will be reviewed as students submit drafts of their proposal for faculty and peer review.  Problem formulation, integrating theoretical frameworks, preparing for human subjects review and outlining data analysis techniques for hypothesis testing will be discussed.  Students will be introduced to University guidelines related to dissertations and other resources to assist them in their task.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of university dissertation guidelines

courseDescription: This course is the first in a series of colloquial courses in which doctoral level students receive presentations and present research and current topics of interest in health related professions.
This course is the second in a series of colloquial courses in which doctoral level students receive presentations and present research and current topics of interest in health related professions.
This course is the third in a series of colloquial courses in which doctoral level students receive presentations and present research and current topics of interest in health related professions.
This course is the fourth in a series of colloquial courses in which doctoral level students receive presentations and present research and current topics of interest in health related professions.
Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in health services.

Individualized study selected by the student in collaboration with a faculty member. Area of study to be supervised and approved by a faculty member with the approval of the graduate program director.
Supervised research on a specialized topic.  Can be repeated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized knowledge in chosen research topic

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  An approved research project written under the supervision of a faculty advisor, in which the student demonstrates the capacity to design and complete independent applied research.  The completed project must be approved by the dissertation committee.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for continuous registration until graduation
